To answer your second question, check out: http://www.xp123.com/xplor/
This site contains a great set of article that act as an introduction to
test-first programming.  What you will find is that if you follow the
test-first paradigm... Yes, the p-word... Your code will be much
simplier to test... =))

However, since you are in a situation of having 200k lines of code, I
would start small...  Only add test cases to code as you need to.  In
otherwords, only create a test case when you need to refactor/change
something.

Otherwise, good luck...

	--Ryan
-----Original Message-----
From: philipborlin@...
[mailto:philipborlin@...] 
Sent: Friday, March 08, 2002 11:31 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Re: JUnit bug for XML testing?



I for one wouldn't mind seeing a bit more beef in the manual or maybe
just a second manual for 'advanced' usage.  I am in charge of getting a
test framework written for an application with over 200K lines of code
that does not have a single test case yet.  Yikes!  It is very confusing
about how to start and how to set up an application level test suite
that will touch all the classes.  I would be willing to write about my
experiences once I figure it out, but that may be some time.

Another thing that would be helpful is some best practices on how to
write code that will be easy to test.

-Phil



 

                    "Ryan P

                    Ripley"               To:
<junit@yahoogroups.com>              
                    <ryan.ripley@z        cc:

                    immer.com>            Subject:     RE: [junit] Re:
JUnit bug for   
                                          XML testing?

                    03/07/2002

                    02:53 PM

                    Please respond

                    to junit

 

 






What kind of documentation would be required?  This is something that I
would be somewhat comfortable getting the ball rolling on.  Basically,
if you could have a user manual that covers junit, what would you want
to see??

Thanks,

           --Ryan

-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
Sent: Thursday, March 07, 2002 3:56 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com; numbsafari
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit bug for XML testing?


Quoting numbsafari <numbsafari@...>:

> Actually, I don't mean to be a critic, but the documentation for 
> J/Unit really sucks. I know, I know... if I don't like it I should do 
> better... [...]

Be critical -- we'll probably all agree with you. What kind of
documentation is missing? I, for one, have written a Starter's Guide.
Mike Clark has a really good primer. Is this not the documentation you
need? Maybe someone with some experience could be convinced to share
some knowledge if there's an area of the framework, its usage or testing
patterns that you need to know about.

Go to the Articles section of http://www.junit.org -- it may help.

J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
President, Diaspar Software Services http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Let's write software that people understand.
